Fallacies.name: False Dichotomy
Fallacies.definition: Presenting only two options when more exist.

Fallacies.name: Ad Hominem
Fallacies.definition: Attacking the person instead of their argument.

Fallacies.name: Straw Man
Fallacies.definition: Misrepresenting someone's position to make it easier to attack.

Fallacies.name: Appeal to Authority
Fallacies.definition: Using an authority’s opinion in place of evidence.

Fallacies.name: Bandwagon
Fallacies.definition: Claiming something is true simply because many believe it.

Fallacies.name: Appeal to Ignorance
Fallacies.definition: Assuming a claim is true/false just because it hasn’t been disproven.

Fallacies.name: Slippery Slope
Fallacies.definition: Asserting a minor action will lead to extreme consequences without evidence.

Fallacies.name: Circular Reasoning
Fallacies.definition: Using the conclusion as a premise.

Fallacies.name: Hasty Generalization
Fallacies.definition: Making broad claims from insufficient examples.

Fallacies.name: Red Herring
Fallacies.definition: Introducing unrelated info to distract from the real issue.

Fallacies.name: False Cause
Fallacies.definition: Assuming causation from sequence alone (“After A happened, B happened; therefore A caused B”).

Fallacies.name: Equivocation
Fallacies.definition: Using a word in different senses across premises.

Fallacies.name: No True Scotsman
Fallacies.definition: Redefining a group to exclude counterexamples (“No true X would do Y”).

Fallacies.name: Tu Quoque (“You too!”)
Fallacies.definition: Dismissing criticism by charging hypocrisy.

Fallacies.name: Appeal to Emotion / Pity
Fallacies.definition: Manipulating feelings instead of using logic.

Fallacies.name: Loaded Question
Fallacies.definition: Asking a question that presumes something unproven.

Fallacies.name: Poisoning the Well
Fallacies.definition: Presenting negative information to discredit someone before they speak.

Fallacies.name: Cherry-picking
Fallacies.definition: Only using data that supports your argument and ignoring the rest.

Fallacies.name: Texas Sharpshooter
Fallacies.definition: Focusing on similarities while ignoring differences to support a point.

Fallacies.name: Gambler’s Fallacy
Fallacies.definition: Believing that past events affect future probability in random situations.

Fallacies.name: Middle Ground
Fallacies.definition: Assuming the middle position between two extremes is always correct.
